awd_titl_txt: CRII: AF: Strongly Polynomial Algorithms for Market Equilibria with Applications to Network Flows and Nash Social Welfare
awd_abstract_narration:
Market equilibrium is a central solution concept in economics with applications in a variety of domains. It has found several surprising applications even in non-market settings which do not involve any exchange of money but only require the remarkable fairness and efficiency properties of equilibria.  These applications include scheduling, mechanism design, fair division, and others. Designing fast algorithms for computing equilibria in markets is vital for their many applications.

For a number of classical market settings with divisible goods, computing an equilibrium reduces to maximizing the geometric mean of agents' utilities, called the Nash social welfare. Nash social welfare is also considered an important fairness notion in allocating scarce resources in a non-market setting. Recently there has been a surge of interest in finding such an allocation with indivisible goods. However, the problem is NP-hard even when there are only two agents with additive valuations, and hence designing fast and near-optimal approximation algorithms is a crucial problem in this domain.

The PI aims to obtain fast algorithms for computing equilibria in fundamental market models and their extensions, and for the Nash welfare problem. Many of these reduce to network flow problems, which are central optimization problems that arise in numerous applications such as transportation and communication. Despite the extensive work on equilibrium computation and network flows, designing a strongly polynomial time algorithm for many of these market models has been long open. The first main thrust of this project is to make progress towards settling these open questions. New algorithmic techniques and tools, as well as structural insights will need to be developed to solve them. Recent work on the Nash welfare problem crucially uses the market model extensions and their connections with the flow problems. The second main thrust of this project is to obtain improved approximation algorithms for the Nash welfare problem.

The project will support and engage two PhD students, and an undergraduate student to implement the designed algorithms and test them for their practical efficiency. The new algorithmic techniques developed in this project will be incorporated into a graduate course on Games and Markets that the PI teaches. All the educational and implementation material will be made freely available online.

por.por_cntn:
Market equilibrium is one of the most fundamental solution concepts in economics to study prices (and allocation) of goods where demand meets supply. Due to the remarkable fairness and efficiency properties of equilibrium allocation, it also has several applications in non-market settings such as fair division of scarce resources even when there may be no money involved. Most of these applications rely on fast algorithms for computing equilibrium. The project makes substantial advances in designing such algorithms and obtaining state-of-the-art results for fair division problems. Below we describe some of the major findings.


The project's work settles a long-standing open question in equilibrium computation by obtaining a fast (strongly polynomial time) algorithm for the classic linear Arrow-Debreu (exchange) market model. Agents come to market with their goods (money can be treated as a good), and they seek to exchange goods among themselves to maximize their individual (linear) utilities. The PI and coauthor develop a new algorithmic technique that also solves a class of optimization problems in strongly polynomial time. This technique might be useful for extending such results to many related problems in optimization.


In fair division, the Nash social welfare is one of the most commonly used measures of efficiency, where the goal is to find an allocation that maximizes the product of agents' utilities. When goods are divisible such as cake, these allocations coincide with market equilibrium allocations. However, when goods are indivisible such as artworks, finding a Nash welfare-maximizing allocation is an intractable problem under standard complexity-theoretic assumptions. Hence, designing fast and near-optimal algorithms is an important problem in this area. The project's work obtains many results in this direction under different agents' utility settings.


On the other hand, perhaps the most natural fairness concept in fair division is of envy-freeness, where everyone likes their own allocation more (or equally) than anyone else's. Again, when goods are divisible, maximum Nash welfare implies envy-freeness; hence it also shows the existence of such an allocation. However, when goods are indivisible, an envy-free allocation may not exist; for example, consider allocating a single valuable good among two agents. Its mild relaxation envy-freeness up to any good (EFX) is arguably the most compelling fairness notions in discrete settings, where no agent envies other's allocation after the removal of any single good. We did not know whether an EFX allocation always exists or not beyond the simple case of two agents. The project's work shows the existence of an EFX allocation for three agents using a new technique, which may also be useful to settle this problem for an arbitrary number of agents. This work is valuable in many disciplines such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, social sciences, and mathematics, as well as it is likely to improve the performance guarantees of online platforms for computing fair allocation in a variety of problems.


The project involved and partially supported multiple students at all levels (including four women) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. For the dissemination of research in the community, the project also funded travels to top conferences in theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. The PI has incorporated many results of the project's work into the undergraduate and graduate courses, he teaches.
